heart_attack: Have the person sit/lie down in a comfortable position; loosen tight clothing.
If the person is conscious and not allergic, give 1 adult aspirin (300 mg) to chew, unless contraindicated.
Begin CPR if the person becomes unresponsive and is not breathing normally.
If trained, use an AED if available.
stroke: Call emergency services immediately — note the time symptoms began.
Keep the person calm and lying down with head slightly elevated.
Do not give food, drink or medications unless directed by a professional.
Monitor breathing and consciousness; begin CPR if needed.
severe_bleeding: Apply direct pressure to wound with clean cloth or bandage.
Elevate the bleeding area above heart level if possible.
Do not remove embedded objects — apply padding around them.
burns: Cool the burn under running water for 10–20 minutes.
Remove constricting items (rings, watches) before swelling starts.
Cover with sterile, non-fluffy dressing or cling film.
Do not apply creams, oils, or ice directly to severe burns.
fracture: Immobilize the limb; do not try to realign bones.
Apply a splint above and below the fracture if possible.
Control any bleeding with direct pressure.
choking: If the person can cough or speak, encourage coughing.
If they cannot breathe, perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich) on conscious adults.
For unconscious patients, start CPR and call emergency services.
allergic_reaction: Call emergency services immediately for severe reactions (difficulty breathing, swelling).
If the person has an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen), use it as prescribed.
Lay the person flat; elevate legs unless this makes breathing worse.
drowning: Remove the person from water and call emergency services.
If trained, begin rescue breaths and CPR as needed.
Keep the person warm and monitor breathing until help arrives.
